pageData.text: Blood typing is conducted to determine a person’s blood group. The ABO blood types are determined by genes on chromosome 9 and are not influenced by environmental factors. In this activity, students are introduced to the ABO and Rh blood typing systems, the process of <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button>, and how it is used in the typing of human blood. Students perform blood typing using human blood.

Digital camera (or mobile device with camera)

pageData.text: Important Note for Instructors: This investigation involves the student disclosing his or her blood type to the instructor in the Lab Notebook. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: Blood Typing with EldonCards

text: Determine your blood type using an EldonCard with three test fields and one control field.
Describe the factors determining ABO and Rh blood types and their inheritance.
Describe the importance of determining blood groups, and identify compatible blood types for transfusion.

Predict <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button> reactions when incompatible whole blood encounters <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> from blood <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button>.

pageData.text: The first recorded person-to-person blood transmission occurred in 1795, leading physicians to see great promise in the new technique. In 1818, the first successful transfusion of human blood was used for the treatment of a postpartum hemorrhage. Physicians continued to perform transfusions to treat a variety of illnesses, sometimes successfully, sometimes not so successfully. As advancements were made, blood types and Rh blood groups were identified, and anticoagulants were developed that allowed for long-term storage of blood. In 1941, the Red Cross began collecting blood for the U.S. military.

According to the Red Cross, more than 38,000 people need a blood transfusion per day in the U.S. Just one pint of blood can be used to save three people. The Red Cross reports that there are often blood shortages, but during the global COVID-19 pandemic the shortage became so perilous that the Red Cross declared a blood emergency. The Red Cross reports that every year the need for blood increases. Research is being conducted to address this issue, and many hope that synthetic blood substitutes will become available as a common treatment in the near future.

pageData.desc: A collection of bags of donated blood.
pageData.altText: A collection of bags of donated blood.

pageData.text: When an individual receives a blood transfusion, it is critically important to match his or her blood type to that of appropriate donor blood. A mismatch could result in a serious and potentially fatal transfusion reaction. The reaction between mismatched blood types occurs because the recipient has <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button>, proteins generated by the immune system, in his or her blood <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button> (the liquid portion of blood, minus clotting factors). These antibodies recognize and bind specifically to <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button>, molecules on the surfaces of the donor’s red blood cells (RBCs). This causes clumping, or <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button>, of the donor RBCs.
There are a variety of different antigens on the surface of RBCs. The two most important types to consider for a blood transfusion are the and the

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A table of the AB0 system of blood and the IgM antibodies present in the blood plasma

pageData.text: The presence or absence of A and B can be used to identify an individual's blood type within the . If someone has type A blood, this means that his or her RBCs carry the on their surfaces, and the immune system produces specific to the B antigen. If he or she receives blood donated by someone with B or AB blood, the anti-B antibodies will bind to the , causing the RBCs to agglutinate. Likewise, a person with type B blood has the B antigen on the RBCs, and produces antibodies against the A antigen. Someone with type AB blood has both A and B antigens, and does not produce antibodies against either antigen. An individual with type O blood has neither A nor B antigens, and generates antibodies against both A and B.

The D antigen belongs to the Rh blood group system, which was named for the rhesus monkeys in which it was first studied. A D- positive individual has the D antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and does not produce anti-D antibodies. A D-negative person lacks the D antigen, and will produce anti-D antibodies. The D antigen is not only important for matching the transfusion to the recipient’s blood, it is also a consideration during pregnancy and birth. <button class='glossary-text'>Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN)</button>, an often fatal condition, may occur when a woman who is D-negative carries a D-positive fetus. This situation can only arise if the father is D-positive; if both parents are D-negative, there is no risk of the fetus being D-positive. However, if the fetus is D-positive, the mother’s anti-D antibodies may cross the placenta, enter the bloodstream of the fetus, and attack the RBCs. HDN does not usually occur with the first D-positive fetus, because the mother’s immune system is not exposed to the antigen until the time of birth. However, if the mother later becomes pregnant with another D-positive fetus, her immune system will produce anti-D antibodies. HDN once caused the deaths of many babies. However, an injection of anti-D antibodies during pregnancy can shield the antigen from the immune system, thus protecting the fetus.

pageData.question: The condition hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) would likely occur in which of the following situations?

options.text: a Rh-negative woman carries a Rh-positive fetus
an individual with type A blood receives a donation of type O blood
a Rh-positive woman carries a Rh-positive fetus
a Rh-positive woman carries a Rh-negative fetus
an individual with type O blood receives a donation of type AB blood

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: HDN is an often-fatal condition that may occur when a Rh-negative woman carries a Rh-positive fetus.

pageData.question: What does it mean if an individual has type A blood?

options.text: They have A antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-B antibodies.
They have B antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-A antibodies.
They have A antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-A antibodies.
They have Rh antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-D antibodies.
They lack Rh antigens on the surfaces of RBCs and produce anti-B antibodies.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Someone with type A blood carries the A antigen on the surfaces of RBCs, and the immune system produces anti-B antibodies.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are several different antigens on the surface of RBCs. The two most important types to consider for a blood transfusion are the A and/or B antigens and the Rh (or D) antigen. The Rh antigen belongs to the Rh blood group system, which was named for the rhesus monkeys in which it was first studied. A Rh-positive individual has the Rh antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and does not produce anti-Rh antibodies. A Rh-negative person lacks the Rh antigen and will produce anti-Rh antibodies. The Rh antigen is not only important for matching the transfusion to the recipient’s blood, but it is also a consideration during pregnancy and birth.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are several different antigens on the surface of RBCs. The two most important types to consider for a blood transfusion are the A and/or B antigens and the Rh (or D) antigen. The Rh antigen belongs to the Rh blood group system, which was named for the rhesus monkeys in which it was first studied. A Rh-positive individual has the Rh antigen on the surfaces of RBCs and does not produce anti-Rh antibodies. A Rh-negative person lacks the Rh antigen and will produce anti-Rh antibodies. The Rh antigen is not only important for matching the transfusion to the recipient’s blood, but it is also a consideration during pregnancy and birth.

img.alt: Figure 1: A table of the AB0 system of blood and the IgM antibodies present in the blood plasma

pageData.text: When you combine the ABO and Rh blood groups, you have the basic information needed to start crossmatching blood donors and recipients. Someone with type A+ blood, for example, could safely receive blood from another individual with type A+ blood. In an emergency situation with no A+ donor blood available, he or she could receive blood from certain other blood types: A–, O+, or O–. Types B+, B–, AB+, and AB– could not be used, because the A+ recipient’s anti-B <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> would cause the donated cells to agglutinate. It is important to remember that ABO and Rh are only two of many different blood type groups, and there are some rare blood types besides these two commonly-used systems.
The <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button> and antibodies associated with each of the different ABO and Rh blood types are summarized in the table below.

The inheritance of blood types is well understood. Inheritance of ABO blood groups is of particular interest because it provides an example of : a situation in which two different versions, or , of the same gene are both expressed. The IA or IB allele codes for enzymes that catalyze the binding of , respectively, to the surface of RBCs. The i allele eliminates the ability to bind A or B antigens. Thus, an individual with the type A blood (observable trait) could have the (genetic makeup) IAIA or the genotype IAi. Likewise, someone with type B blood could have genotypes IBIB or IBi. Type AB blood requires the IAIB genotype, and type O blood means the genotype is ii.

People with type O blood were once thought to lack on the surface of their RBCs, and those with type O– blood were referred to as “universal donors.” We now know that all the ABO blood groups have a weak H antigen. The presence of the IA or IB allele actually codes for enzymes that catalyze the binding of the A or B antigen to the H antigen. The i allele eliminates the ability to bind A or B antigens to the H antigen; therefore, type O RBCs have more exposed H antigen.

The production of H antigen is controlled by a gene locus with two alleles (H and h) on chromosome 19. These are independent of the ABO locus, which is on chromosome 9. The h allele is rare, and the genotype hh, therefore, is very rare. The hh individuals produce RBCs without the H antigen, a condition called the , named for Bombay, India, where it was first discovered. In the absence of the H antigen, antigens A and B have nothing with which to bind. As a result, when individuals possessing the Bombay phenotype are tested with anti-A and anti-B , they appear to belong to group O. However, these individuals cannot receive blood from type O donors who have H antigens, because their hh RBCs are agglutinated by anti-H antibodies.

pageData.question: In an emergency, someone with type A+ blood could receive which of the following types of blood?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Someone with type A+ blood could receive blood from certain other blood types: A–, O+, or O–. Other types could not be used because the A+ recipient’s anti-B antibodies would cause the donated cells to agglutinate.

pageData.question: In an emergency, someone with type O- blood could receive which of the following types of blood?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Someone with type O- blood could only receive more O- blood. This blood type contains antibodies against A, B, and D antigens, causing it to agglutinate any other blood types.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When the ABO and Rh blood groups are combined, the basic information needed to start cross-matching blood donors and recipients is obtained. It is important to remember that ABO and Rh are only two of several different groups of blood types, and there are some rare blood types besides these two commonly used systems. People with type O blood were once thought to lack antigens on the surface of their RBCs, and those with type O– blood were referred to as “universal donors.” We now know that all ABO blood groups have a weak H antigen.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: When the ABO and Rh blood groups are combined, the basic information needed to start cross-matching blood donors and recipients is obtained. It is important to remember that ABO and Rh are only two of several different groups of blood types, and there are some rare blood types besides these two commonly used systems. People with type O blood were once thought to lack antigens on the surface of their RBCs, and those with type O– blood were referred to as “universal donors.” We now know that all ABO blood groups have a weak H antigen.

pageData.subTitle: About EldonCards
pageData.text: The EldonCard method of blood typing is designed for easy portability, storage, and use. Other methods of blood type testing use liquid sera containing specific <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button>, which must be stored in a refrigerator. The sera are mixed with whole blood on special slides. EldonCards do not need to be refrigerated, and require no additional reagents or equipment, other than a container of tap water and a pipette. Each test field on an EldonCard contains a small amount of dried antibodies obtained from a source free of potentially disease-causing microbes. Adding water causes renaturation and activation of the antibodies. Tilting the EldonCard during the test reduces the chances of obtaining false positive results by preventing nonspecific <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button>. The control field lacks antibodies, so no agglutination should occur in the control if the test is conducted correctly.

pageData.question: Why should you not expect any agglutination in the control field of an EldonCard?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The EldonCard control field lacks antibodies, so no agglutination should occur in the control if the test is conducted correctly.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the general steps of the EldonCard method of blood typing?

options.text: renature antisera fields with water, add blood to fields, tilt EldonCard
add antisera to fields, add blood to fields, add water to fields, tilt EldonCard
add blood to fields, tilt EldonCard, add antisera to fields
add blood to fields and let dry, renature dried blood with water, add antisera to fields
add water to fields, add antibodies to fields, tilt EldonCard, add blood to fields

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: To blood type using an EldonCard, add water to the test fields to renature the antibodies, add blood to each field, then tilt the EldonCard as it dries.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will fill a beaker with water and prepare your disinfectant. In activity 1, you will add a drop of water to each test field on the Eldon card. Then, you will clean your finger with alcohol and puncture it with a safety lancet. Next, you will capture a drop of blood with a clean Eldon stick and transfer it to blank test field. You will repeat this process until there is blood in each test field. Then, you will spread the blood within each test field. Next, you will tilt the Eldon card as it dries. Then, you will observe each field for agglutination and determine your blood type. Finally, you will photograph your Eldon card.

Then, you will spread the blood within each test field. Next, you will tilt the Eldon card as it dries. Then, you will observe each field for agglutination and determine your blood type. Finally, you will photograph your Eldon card.

pageData.text: Reorder Information:Replacement supplies for the Blood Typing with EldonCards investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, item number 699921.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your goggles and lab apron at all times while conducting this investigation.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing lab activities, and wash your hands before beginning and after obtaining your blood sample. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use this near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.

Only your own blood should be used in this investigation. As a best practice, all human blood should always be treated as if it may contain potentially infectious microbes. At the conclusion of this laboratory exercise, all materials that have come into contact with your blood should be soaked in 10% bleach solution before they may be disposed of safely.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: After completing this investigation, all materials that have come in contact with your blood should be soaked in a 10% bleach solution for an hour before disposal.  Which of the following best explains the reasoning behind this disposal procedure?

options.text: Human blood should always be treated as if it contains potentially infectious microbes.
Human blood always contains viruses that can spread if not properly disinfected.
Human blood will stain materials if not treated with bleach before washing.
Human blood should always be treated as if it contains Rh factor.
Human blood is toxic if ingested and should be neutralized before disposal.

Review the background information and activity instructions.
Obtain all materials.
Fill a beaker with tap water.
Fill another beaker with a 10% bleach solution (1 part household laundry bleach to 9 parts tap water).

Caution: Wear appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) when working with bleach: gloves, lab apron, and chemical splash goggles. Ensure adequate ventilation when using bleach; if possible, open a window.
In Activity 1, you will apply your own blood to an EldonCard. You will then observe each field for <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button> and determine your blood type.

pages.title: Temperature vs. Time to Dissolve
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Blood Typing with EldonCards (11 steps)

pageData.text: Using the plastic dropping pipette, place a drop of water onto each of the test fields and the control field on the EldonCard.
Wipe the fingertip from which you will draw blood with the alcohol swab. Set the swab aside.
Caution: Use only your own blood.
Puncture the skin of your fingertip with the sterile lancet.
Caution: Do not open the lancet package until you are ready to draw blood. As long as the lancet package is intact, the lancet will remain sterile.
Run the fingers of your opposite hand down towards the fingertip in order to encourage bleeding.
Once a large drop of blood is present, pick it up with an EldonStick. Hold the EldonStick underneath the finger as you capture the drop of blood. Avoid smearing the blood over your skin.
Place the EldonStick onto the first field of the EldonCard so that the blood runs into the drop of water. Set the EldonStick aside.

Repeat steps 4–6 with the remaining three fields of the EldonCard, using a fresh EldonStick each time. Keep track of which EldonStick was used with each field. Do not discard the EldonSticks until you have obtained your test results.
Caution: Keep blood transferred with each EldonStick in its designated card field (Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: An EldonCard on which an EldonStick and a small volume of blood lie on each of four circular test fields.

pageData.text: Stir the blood in each field with its designated EldonStick for about 10 seconds each. Next, spread the blood over each of the appropriate fields.
Caution: You must start to stir the blood in each field within two minutes after application, to avoid clotting.
Hold the EldonCard in a vertical position and wait for 10 seconds. Tilt to the opposite vertical position and wait 10 more seconds. Tilt to the right and left, holding for 10 seconds each.

To read your test results, examine each field to see if <button class='glossary-text'>agglutination</button> has occurred. This is indicated by a grainy appearance. Non-agglutinated blood will have a smooth and consistent appearance. A control field should always have non-agglutinated blood; otherwise, the test is considered invalid. Results for each blood type are summarized in Table 2.
Document your results by placing your EldonCard on a piece of white paper. Photograph the EldonCard, making sure that all fields are clearly visible.

text: Discard the alcohol swab in the garbage.
Place the used lancet in the beaker of bleach solution.
When you are certain that you have acceptable photographic documentation from your EldonCard, add it to the bleach. Soak for at least 1 hour.
Place the lancet in a hard-sided container, such as a plastic bottle or aluminum can, before placing it in the garbage.
Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.
All other investigation materials may be disposed of as household trash.
Sanitize the workspace.

data.title: A antigen
data.content: A type of red blood cell surface protein used in the ABO blood group system

data.title: ABO group system
data.content: A system for categorizing human blood that denotes the presence of one, both, or neither of the A and B antigens on red blood cells (RBCs)

data.title: Agglutination
data.content: The sticking together of cells into a clump or mass

data.title: Alleles
data.content: Two or more versions of a gene

data.title: Antibodies
data.content: antigen-binding proteins generated by the immune system

data.title: Antigens
data.content: molecules on the surface of cells and disease-causing agents

data.title: B antigen
data.content: A type of red blood cell surface protein used in the ABO blood group system

data.title: Bombay phenotype
data.content: A condition in which individuals do not express the H antigen

data.title: Codominance
data.content: A situation in which two different versions of the same gene are both expressed

data.title: Genotype
data.content: The genetic makeup of an individual cell or organism that determines or contributes to the phenotype

data.title: Hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN)
data.content: An often fatal condition that may occur when an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive fetus

data.title: Phenotype
data.content: The physical expression of a trait

data.title: Rh (D) antigen
data.content: A type of red blood cell surface protein used in the Rh blood group system

data.title: Serum
data.content: The liquid portion of the blood without clotting factors
